Customer experience is a key competitive factor not only for the financial services industry but almost all industries.
Customer service will be the solution to retaining customers, encouraging spending, and motivating them to return for the next purchase journey. With the rapid development of the economy, quality customer service will be the lifeblood that sustains all types of businesses.

So how can banks improve customer service quality? This is one of the major challenges that bank leaders must face.

Below are 8 ways banks can deliver outstanding customer services:

1. Equip Customers with Financial Knowledge

According to a recent study from the Raddon Research Institute, financially literate customers are more profitable for banks because “they tend to have higher credit activity and greater use of financial products.”
This means banks can participate in or sponsor financial literacy training programs.

A financial education program is a great way to improve customer service in banking. If developing an in-house program is too costly, banks can collaborate with associations or partner with other organizations to leverage existing resources and expand upon them.

2. Become a Trusted Advisor for Small Business Customers

To gain the trust and loyalty of small business owners, your bank must transition from being a lender to becoming a financial advisor by providing comprehensive services designed to help small businesses grow.

The goal is to partner with small businesses in a way that you’re not just a lender but a reliable advisor in their long-term development. You must also continue to deepen existing small business relationships to prevent them from switching to fintech firms or other competitors like Amazon or Facebook. To achieve this, banks need to assess which areas small businesses must adapt in order to take full advantage of new technologies.

3. Make Data a Core Component of Customer Service Strategy

Contextual data can be used to identify behaviors and relationships that banks can leverage to inform and enrich the customer experience. In fact, contextual data can improve customer service in banking by enabling financial institutions to develop customized products and services that match each customer’s needs.

For example: to address the challenge of collecting payments from customers, Finland-based digital banking startup Holvi developed an e-invoicing system that allows customers to “create professional-looking digital invoices, automatically fill in payment details, and send alerts to the customer’s phone when payments are received, with real-time updates.”

Every piece of information you collect can be used to build detailed profiles that provide a 360-degree view of the customer. These profiles can be stored in a central CRM repository, giving staff easy access to make more informed decisions when responding to customer service requests, developing targeted marketing campaigns, upselling, and cross-selling.

4. Develop an Omnichannel Customer Experience

Although it’s easy to assume that with people’s attachment to mobile devices, banking is heading toward a fully digital future – the numbers suggest otherwise. According to Reuters, 60% of Americans still prefer opening a new checking account at a physical branch rather than through digital channels. Even more encouraging, Accenture reports that 86% of consumers intend to visit a physical branch in the future and desire face-to-face human interaction.

This doesn’t mean banks should prioritize branches over digital development. Instead, the key is to combine digital and traditional components to create an omnichannel customer experience. Banks must map out customer touchpoints to understand how this type of experience improves service quality.

5. Provide Customers with Self-Service Opportunities

Customers want independence: they want to do things on their own.

Self-service has exploded across industries, with 74% of customers saying they have previously used self-service support portals, and 81% reporting that they attempted to resolve issues on their own before contacting a bank’s customer service.

In a world where everyone seems glued to their smartphones, the benefits of mobile banking are clear. In fact, nearly every institution already has its own branded mobile app. But that doesn’t mean banks are leveraging their apps to the fullest potential.

6. Equip Your Employees for Success

First and foremost, banks must invest in comprehensive training, as training methods in the banking sector are rapidly evolving—from virtual simulations to gamification, with continuous technology updates.

The next step is to build an internal knowledge system that staff can reference when faced with customer questions they cannot immediately answer. This centralized repository should contain everything from policies and procedures to relevant industry regulations, organized and easy to navigate. It must also be regularly updated to ensure only accurate and relevant information is available.

Finally, empower employees with cutting-edge front-end and back-office banking technologies. From CRM solutions providing data-driven customer insights for a 360-degree view, to predictive analytics systems preventing fraud—an integrated ecosystem of tools is a real asset to your team. Most importantly, ensure these systems are seamlessly connected, so customer service staff do not need to switch between platforms when handling requests.

7. Solicit Customer Feedback Whenever Possible

No one understands customers better than the customers themselves. While a bank’s CRM data can reveal customer profiles and predictive behaviors, technology no matter how advanced cannot uncover what’s truly on a customer’s mind.

That’s why banks must frequently seek customer feedback: to learn whether their needs are being met, which products or services interest them, their future goals, and how their experience can be improved.

Practical approaches include:

  • Adding a feedback step at every customer interaction. For example, after a call center conversation, staff can ask if the customer has further questions and whether they were satisfied with the service.

  • Embedding short surveys (two to three questions) on the bank’s website after customers complete transactions.

Each new data point enriches the customer base and helps the bank make smarter decisions to enhance customer experience.

8. Stay Flexible and Open to Change

The financial services landscape is constantly evolving, with new trends emerging every day. To ensure your bank delivers the best possible customer experience, you must stay in tune with industry dynamics and remain adaptable. This means continuously seeking improvements, keeping your solutions ecosystem integrated and updated, and embracing digital transformation.

By listening to customers, maintaining an open mindset, and making smart investments, you can guarantee exceptional customer service in your bank.

Source: McKinsey & Company
